{
  "Q1": "What are Krishi Vigyan Kendras (KVKs) and what is their primary objective?",
  "A1": "KVKs are agricultural extension centres established by the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) in India, aiming to improve the livelihoods of farmers by bridging the gap between researchers and farmers through agricultural technology dissemination.",
  "Q2": "What activities do KVKs undertake to achieve their objectives?",
  "A2": "KVKs conduct on-farm trials, organize training programs, demonstrate improved agricultural technologies, provide advisory services, and organize field days and exhibitions.",
  "Q3": "How do KVKs contribute to agricultural development and rural livelihood improvement in India?",
  "A3": "KVKs play a vital role in empowering farmers with knowledge and resources to adopt sustainable and modern agricultural practices, thereby contributing to agricultural development and rural livelihood improvement in India.",
  "Q4": "What stakeholders do KVKs collaborate with to maximize their outreach and impact?",
  "A4": "KVKs collaborate with agricultural universities, research institutions, government departments, NGOs, and local communities.",
  "Q5": "What is the role of KVKs in capacity building?",
  "A5": "KVKs focus on capacity building of extension personnel, agripreneurs, rural youth, and women in agriculture through skill development and training programs.",
  "Q6": "What is the significance of the G20-MACS event mentioned in the cover of the issue?",
  "A6": "The G20-MACS event mentioned in the cover of the issue is likely a significant agricultural or economic conference attended by G20 member countries, focusing on agriculture and related issues.",
  "Q7": "What is the purpose of the Krishi Vigyan Kendras Glorious Journey of Five Decades?",
  "A7": "The purpose of the Krishi Vigyan Kendras Glorious Journey of Five Decades is to commemorate and reflect on the achievements and progress of KVKs over the past fifty years.",
  "Q8": "What is the KVK Portal of ICAR, and what does it aim to provide?",
  "A8": "The KVK Portal of ICAR is an online platform that aims to provide a comprehensive guide to KVKs, their activities, and resources available to farmers and stakeholders.",
  "Q9": "What is the surface seeding-cum-mulching technique, and how is it used?",
  "A9": "The surface seeding-cum-mulching technique is an emerging option to manage crop residue, which involves sowing seeds directly on the soil surface and covering them with mulch to conserve moisture and suppress weeds.",
  "Q10": "How is the utilization of crop residue as an asset beneficial for crop nutrients and soil health?",
  "A10": "Utilizing crop residue as an asset helps in managing crop residues, conserving soil moisture, and maintaining soil health by adding organic matter and nutrients to the soil."
}

"Q: What are Krishi Vigyan Kendras (KVKs) and their role in Indian agriculture?",
"A: KVKs are frontline extension systems in India's agricultural landscape, providing training, demonstrations, technology assessment, and capacity development.",

"A: KVKs were established in 1974, and there are currently 731 KVKs operating across the country.",

"Q: What are some significant achievements of KVKs in enhancing agricultural productivity and sustainability?",
"A: KVKs have achieved significant milestones such as the adoption of innovative initiatives like Cluster Frontline Demonstrations and District Agriculture Contingency Plans, which have enhanced agricultural productivity and sustainability.",
"Q: What are the challenges faced by KVKs?",
"A: KVKs face challenges such as workforce constraints and administrative issues.",
"Q: What is the role of KVKs in driving inclusive and resilient agricultural development?",
"A: KVKs play a pivotal role in driving inclusive and resilient agricultural development by providing training, demonstrations, and capacity development to farmers and rural stakeholders.",
"Q: What are the future prospects for KVKs in Indian agriculture?",
"A: The future prospects for KVKs in Indian agriculture include adapting to rapid technological advancements and climate change, strengthening linkages with research institutions, leveraging digital technologies, and promoting climate-smart agriculture.",

"A: Celebrating the Golden Jubilee Year of KVKs is significant as it recognizes their remarkable growth, achievements, and transformative impact on Indian agriculture over the past fifty years.",

"A: KVKs can continue to evolve and adapt by strengthening linkages with research institutions, leveraging digital technologies, and promoting climate-smart agriculture.",

"A: The Special Issue of Indian Farming is expected to be very informative and useful to farmers, extension functionaries, and farm entrepreneurs by providing insights into crucial facets of resource management, integrated pest management, ecosystem dynamics, women's empowerment, livelihood diversification, precision agriculture, and digital agriculture."

"Q: How did the demand for food grains and other agricultural commodities change as the population grew?"
"A: As the population grew, the demand for food grains and other agricultural commodities increased."
"Q: What led to the intensification of agriculture?"
"A: The intensification of agriculture was due to the growing population and the need to produce more per unit area."
"Q: What are the consequences of indiscriminate exploitation and intensive agricultural practices?"
"A: These practices have caused damage to the finite natural resources."
"Q: What is the only option left when the luxury of horizontal spread of cropping is drying up?"
"A: The only option left is vertical intensification for producing more per unit area."
"Q: Why is the sustainability of natural resources a concern?"
"A: It is a concern due to the competing demands of various land uses and the problem of not only depleting but also deteriorating natural resources."
"Q: What percentage of the total geographic area is estimated to be affected by the problem of depleting and deteriorating natural resources?"
"A: About 37% of the total geographic area is estimated to be affected."
"Q: What are the major challenges faced by agriculture in terms of natural resources?"
"A: The major challenges include the limited availability of land and water, and the impact of climate change on agricultural productivity."
"Q: How can the sustainability of natural resources be ensured?"
"A: Sustainable practices such as efficient water management, soil conservation, and climate-resilient technologies can help ensure the sustainability of natural resources."
"Q: What are some examples of sustainable practices that can be adopted in agriculture?"
"A: Examples include efficient water management, soil conservation, and climate-resilient technologies."
}

"Q: What are small millets and their significance in Indian agriculture?",

"A: In Madhya Pradesh, both kodo and little millet are predominant, while foxtail millet is important in Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka.",

"Q: What are the key documents related to the Green India Mission and farmers' support in India?
A: The key documents include Force on Greening India (2001), National Policy on Farmers (2007), and Green India Mission (2010).
Q: What role does NABARD play in promoting agroforestry in India?
A: NABARD provides financial and banking institutional support for the promotion of agroforestry models developed by ICAR.
Q: Why is there a growing focus on chemical-free farming in India?
A: Higher agricultural production is associated with higher chemical footprints, leading to land degradation, water and air pollution, unhealthy ecosystems, and risks to human health.
Q: When did ICAR initiate the pilot study on chemical-free farming, and what was its focus?
A: ICAR initiated the pilot study in 2017 under the All India Network Programme on Organic Farming, focusing on zero-budget farming practices in the basmati/coarse rice-wheat system.
Q: What were the results of the evaluation of natural farming concoctions compared to integrated crop management in India?
A: The experiment conducted from 2017-2020 showed that natural farming concoctions of Jeevamrit, Beejamrit, and Ghanjeevamrit were compared with integrated crop management and AI-NPOF developed organic farming package.
Q: What management practices have been initiated since kharif 2020 in India?
A: Evaluation and validation of Beejamrit, Jeevamrit, Ghanjeevamrit; intercropping; mulching, and Whapasa have been initiated at 20 locations in 16 states.
Q: What is the geographical area covered by the arid zone of India?
A: The arid zone of India covers about 12% of the country's geographical area, which is approximately 32 million hectares.
Q: When was the Central Arid Zone Research Institute (CAZRI) established, and what is its significance?
A: CAZRI was established in 1952 and is significant for its research work on stabilization of sand dunes, establishment of shelterbelts, and development of agroforestry models for arid environments.
Q: What are the achievements of CAZRI in the field of agri-voltaic systems?
A: CAZRI has developed and utilized the concept of agri-voltaic systems, resulting in 1,29,266 kWh annual power output from a single land use, and has developed 13 operational agri-voltaic systems in the country.
Q: What technology has CAZRI developed for gum exudation, and where has it been adopted?
A: CAZRI developed a technology for gum exudation from Acacia senegal, which has been adopted in western Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, and Gujarat.
Q: What crops have been successfully grown in the inter-panel spaces of agri-voltaic systems in India?
A: Short-statured kharif and rabi pulses, spices, and vegetables have been successfully grown in the inter-panel spaces of agri-voltaic systems in India."}

  "A9": "Some of the technological milestones in the field of food processing include Warehouses for bag storage (1950s), Rubber roll-based rice mills, roller flour mills (1960s), Metallic storage bin, mechanical winnower, solvent extraction of edible oil (1970s), Solvent extraction plants for soybean, food extrusion (1970s), First hot air dehydrator for raisins, apricot, etc. (1975), Electrical moisture meters, LSU dryers, Introduction of Agro-processing centers (1980s), Frozen seafood & RTE meals (1988), Launch of SAFAL–organized retail network of fruits and vegetables (1988), Introduction of colour sorter for rice (1990s), Air Dried, Freeze Dried and IQF products (1993), First local brand of 100% pure natural fruit juices (1996), First Indian cold room as per international standards (1997), Hermetic storage of food grains (2000s), Non-destructive methods for food safety & quality (2004), Indigenous tomato and kinnow processing plant (2004), CIPHET-Evaporative cooled storage structure for fruits & vegetables (2006), Special horticulture train for fruits & vegetables (2012), Commercial unit of makhana popping machine (2013), Introduction of Kisan rail (dedicated train for perishables) (2020).",

{ "Q: What role did Dr. Zakir Hussain play in the Green Revolution in India?"
  "A: Dr. Zakir Hussain, then Vice-President of India, highlighted the collaborative efforts of agricultural scientists, extension workers, farmers, and government policies in the Green Revolution during his 2nd Convocation Address at IARI Campus in 1962."
  "Q: What were the key achievements of the Green Revolution in India?"
  "A: The Green Revolution led to the introduction of technology, transforming agriculture into a modern system, and resulted in increased production of food grains, milk, eggs, fish, meat, and vegetables, contributing to self-sufficiency and food security."
  "Q: How did the Green Revolution impact India's agricultural education system?"
  "A: The Green Revolution emphasized the need for an effective higher education system to build human capital and trained manpower, leading to the establishment of agricultural universities and research institutions."
  "Q: What was the impact of the Green Revolution on wheat production in India?"
  "A: By the 50th anniversary of India's independence, wheat production increased from 29 million tons to 96 million tons, thanks to the Green Revolution."
  "Q: When was the first university education commission of India formed?"
  "A: The first University Education Commission of India was formed in 1948."
  "Q: What was the purpose of the first Indo-American team proposal in 1955?"
  "A: The first Indo-American team proposed the establishment of Land-grant style universities in India."
  "Q: When was IARI granted Deemed University Status?"
  "A: IARI was granted Deemed University Status in 1958."
  "Q: What was the purpose of the second Joint Indo-American Team in 1960?"
  "A: The second Joint Indo-American Team was tasked with framing specific proposals for the third five-year plan in India."
  "Q: How many SAUs were established by 1964?"
  "A: Seven SAUs were established by 1964."
  "Q: When was the first Deans' Committee constituted?"
  "A: The first Deans' Committee was constituted in 1965."
  "Q: What was the purpose of the JRF initiated in 1966?"
  "A: The JRF was initiated for M.Sc. Students in 1966." }

"A: More than 2,70,000 items with 50 million pages have been digitized and stored in KrishiKosh.",
"Q: How many member institutions are currently part of KrishiKosh?",
"A: KrishiKosh currently has 96 member institutions.",
"Q: How many theses from various SAUs have been uploaded to KrishiKosh?",
"A: 1,75,000 theses from various SAUs have been uploaded to KrishiKosh.",
"Q: How many visits and countries have accessed the KrishiKosh site since April 2017?",
"A: Since April 2017, the KrishiKosh site has received 23 million visits from researchers in 175 countries.",
"Q: What is the Agricultural Education Portal and what information does it provide?",
"A: The Agricultural Education Portal is a database of information about all the agricultural universities in India, providing a unified information base for collection, compilation, and analysis of information about the activities of the agricultural education system in India.",
"Q: How has the support provided to strengthen the infrastructure under ICT impacted Agricultural Education in India?",
"A: The support provided to strengthen the infrastructure under ICT has improved dialogue, interaction, communication, and coordination among stakeholders, leading to knowledge sharing, multidisciplinary and collaborative innovations in education and research, and the establishment of quality institutions with requisite facilities."

{
"Q": "What are the main stakeholders involved in the frontline extension system?",
"A": "The frontline extension system is governed by ICAR with SAUs, some reputed NGOs, State Governments, and involves various departments like DAFW, Department of Fisheries, and Department of Animal Husbandry & Dairying.",
"Q": "What is the role of commodity boards under the Ministry of Commerce in agriculture?",
"A": "Commodity boards under the Ministry of Commerce provide mass extension services specific to their commodities.",
"Q": "How do agribusiness houses and input agencies contribute to agricultural extension services?",
"A": "Agribusiness houses and input agencies offer private extension services to farmers, although there may be some conflict of interest.",
"Q": "What is the basic philosophy behind the frontline extension system?",
"A": "The philosophy is that scientists who generated the technologies can demonstrate them better to farmers in their fields, with concurrent and direct feedback for further refinement.",
"Q": "What was the impact of the Community Development Programme (CDP) launched in 1952?",
"A": "The CDP aimed for socio-economic transformation of rural people by increasing agricultural production, tackling unemployment, improving communications, education, health, recreation, housing, promoting indigenous handicrafts, and improving villagers' lives through their own efforts.",
"Q": "What was the significance of the National Demonstration in 1964?",
"A": "The National Demonstration was a precursor to the Green Revolution, demonstrating the genetic potential and generating increased agricultural production.",
"Q": "What were some of the important movements in pre-independence India aimed at rural reconstruction and upliftment?",
"A": "Movements like Sriniketan Project, Sevagram, Marthandam Project, Gurgaon Project, and Firka Development Programme were significant efforts towards rural reconstruction and upliftment.",
"Q": "How did the role of agricultural extension in addressing agrarian challenges evolve over the decades?",
"A": "The role of agricultural extension has changed significantly, with milestones such as the Community Development Programme (CDP) in 1952 and the National Demonstration in 1964 marking key developments in addressing agrarian challenges.",
"Q": "What are the responsibilities of the Department of Agriculture & Farmers Welfare (DAFW) in agricultural extension?",
"A": "The DAFW is responsible for mass extension in agriculture and allied sectors, working through a network of departments at state, district, block, and village levels.",
"Q": "How do agricultural extension services contribute to the overall development of rural society?",
"A": "Agricultural extension services contribute to rural development by addressing agrarian challenges, promoting socio-economic transformation, and improving the livelihood of rural people through various programs and initiatives."
}

{ "Q: What was the primary target of the Government immediately after India's Independence in 1947?", "A: To bring food sufficiency to its citizens.", "Q: How did the community development programme contribute to agricultural education and extension?", "A: It provided a model of land grant pattern for agricultural education and extension.", "Q: What was the initial goal of the Grow-More-Food Campaign?", "A: To increase agricultural production on a pan India approach.", "Q: What was the revised goal of the Grow-More-Food Campaign after India's Independence?", "A: To achieve self-sufficiency in food grains by 1952 with an increase in the production of other crops.", "Q: What approach was adopted in the Grow-More-Food Campaign?", "A: An integrated and coordinated approach.", "Q: What was the role of people’s committees in the Grow-More-Food Campaign?", "A: They mobilized public support at various administrative levels.", "Q: What was the main achievement of the Etawah pilot project?", "A: Significant increase in wheat production due to the adoption of improved agricultural technologies.", "Q: What was the purpose of the Nilokheri project?", "A: To rehabilitate displaced people from West Pakistan by developing a new township." }

  "Q1": "What was the purpose of the Community Development Projects started on 2nd October, 1952?",
  "A1": "To increase agricultural production and improve the overall economic condition of farmers.",
  "Q2": "How many villages and what population range did each Community Development Project cover?",
  "A2": "Each project covered about 300 villages with a population of about two lakhs.",
  "Q3": "How were the project areas divided for development?",
  "A3": "The project area was divided into three development blocks, each comprising 100 villages and a population of 60,000 to 70,000.",
  "Q4": "What was the role of a multipurpose village-level worker in the Community Development Projects?",
  "A4": "To oversee the development of 5-10 villages within each development block.",
  "Q5": "When was the National Extension Service (NES) inaugurated and what was its purpose?",
  "A5": "The NES was inaugurated on 2nd October 1953 to provide essential staff and funds for development work based on self-help.",
  "Q6": "What was the operational unit of the National Extension Service (NES)?",
  "A6": "An N.E.S. block comprising about 100 villages and 60,000 to 70,000 people.",
  "Q7": "How were the N.E.S. blocks later utilized?",
  "A7": "They were converted into community development blocks with higher budget provisions for more intensive development programs.",
  "Q8": "When was the National Demonstration on major food crops launched and what was its purpose?",
  "A8": "Launched in 1964, its purpose was to showcase the superiority of new agricultural practices to local extension agencies/workers.",
  "Q9": "What was the area of the demonstration plot in the National Demonstration?",
  "A9": "About one hectare.",
  "Q10": "What was the High Yielding Variety Programme (HYVP) launched in 1966 intended to achieve?",
  "A10": "To introduce high yielding crop varieties and promote modern agricultural inputs, aiming at self-sufficiency in food production."

  "Q1": "What was the main goal of the National Agricultural Technology Project (NATP) launched by the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR)?",
  "A1": "The main goal of NATP was to strengthen and complement existing resources and augment the output of the National Agricultural Research System (NARS).",
  "Q2": "How much funding did the World Bank provide for the National Agricultural Technology Project (NATP)?",
  "A2": "The World Bank provided funding of Rs. 992 crores for the National Agricultural Technology Project (NATP).",
  "Q3": "What was the lifespan of the National Agricultural Technology Project (NATP)?",
  "A3": "The lifespan of the National Agricultural Technology Project (NATP) was seven years, from 1998 to 2005.",
  "Q4": "What was the total number of projects successfully completed under the National Agricultural Technology Project (NATP)?",
  "A4": "The National Agricultural Technology Project (NATP) successfully completed a total of 852 projects.",
  "Q5": "What was the purpose of the Innovations in Technology Dissemination (ITD) component of NATP?",
  "A5": "The purpose of the Innovations in Technology Dissemination (ITD) component of NATP was to pilot Agricultural Technology Management Agencies (ATMAs) in 28 districts and set up 340 44 Agricultural Technology Information Centres (ATICs) in ICAR Institutes and State Agricultural Universities.",
  "Q6": "What is the current status of India's food production?",
  "A6": "India is now self-sufficient in food production and is also a net exporter of food grains and several other commodities.",
  "Q7": "What are some of the cyclic and structural challenges faced by Indian agriculture today?",
  "A7": "The cyclic and structural challenges faced by Indian agriculture today include price discovery and realization, land fragmentation, and natural resource degradation and depletion under escalating abiotic stresses.",
  "Q8": "What role do Krishi Vigyan Kendras (KVKs) play in Indian agriculture?",
  "A8": "Krishi Vigyan Kendras (KVKs) serve as knowledge and resource centers at the district level, playing a crucial role in location-specific technology development and technology backstopping for development departments or field extension systems.",
  "Q9": "What are some of the programs/projects that played an important role in technology delivery and dissemination in Indian agriculture?",

  "Q10": "What are some of the challenges faced by Indian agriculture today that require addressing to enhance productivity?",
  "A10": "Some of the challenges faced by Indian agriculture today that require addressing to enhance productivity include enhancing productivity of land, labour, and applied inputs, addressing gender and nutritional issues, reducing post-harvest losses and food wastes, attracting rural youth in agriculture with entrepreneurship development and business incubation, and managing natural resource degradation and depletion under the realm of escalating abiotic stresses."

"Q: When were the Agriculture Technology Information Centres (ATICs) established and what is their purpose?",
"A: ATICs were established in 2000 to serve as a single window delivery system for research services and products in areas where the concerned institute is involved.",
"Q: How many ATICs are currently established in ICAR institutes and SAUs?",
"A: There are 44 ATICs established in ICAR institutes and SAUs.",
"Q: What is the objective of the National Agricultural Innovation Project (NAIP)?",
"A: The objective of NAIP is to facilitate the accelerated and sustainable transformation of Indian agriculture in support of poverty alleviation and income generation through collaborative development and application of agricultural innovations.",
"Q: When was the National Agricultural Innovation Project (NAIP) launched?",
"A: NAIP was launched in 2006 by ICAR.",
"Q: What are the major achievements in agricultural extension in independent India?",
"A: Major achievements include the establishment of Krishi Vigyan Kendras (KVKs) in 1974, which merged activities of National Demonstration Project, Operational Research Project, and Lab-to-Land Project, aiming to improve technical literacy of farmers.",
"Q: When and where was the first Krishi Vigyan Kendra (KVK) established?",
"A: The first KVK was established in 1974 at Puducherry (Pondicherry) under the administrative control of Tamil Nadu Agricultural University, Coimbatore.",
"Q: How many KVKs were initially approved by the Planning Commission during the Fifth Five Year Plan Period?",
"A: The Planning Commission approved the establishment of 18 KVKs during the Fifth Five Year Plan Period (1974-79).",
"Q: What was the Cabinet's decision regarding KVKs in 1983-84?",
"A: The Cabinet decided to open one KVK in each district.",
"Q: How many new KVKs were established by ICAR during each 5 Year Plan Period?",
"A: Several new KVKs were established by ICAR during each 5 Year Plan Period.",
"Q: What was the Prime Minister of India's announcement regarding KVKs on Independence Day Speech in 2005?",
"A: The Prime Minister announced that there should be one KVK in each of the rural districts of the country by the end of 2007."

  "Q1": "How many KVKs were established by the end of the Tenth Plan (2002-07)?",

  "Q5": "What are the key contributions of the KVK system in agriculture?",

  "Q8": "What is the role of ATMA?",

  "Q9": "How has the approach to agricultural extension changed over time?",
  "A9": "The approach to agricultural extension has changed from a production, productivity focus to income and marketing efficiency, from a pedagogic education system to on-the-job vocational training, from a decentralized bottom-to-top approach to sustainable agricultural practices, and from resource exploitation to farmer participation.",
  "Q10": "What is the philosophy behind the farmer participatory approach in extension?",

"Q: What is the demand for makhana in north Bihar and how does it affect local wholesalers and agents?",
"A: The demand for makhana in north Bihar creates opportunities for local wholesalers and agents to benefit by transporting it to distant markets, where its price is generally 60-70% higher than the local market.",
"Q: Why is makhana considered to have a significant value-addition in transportation?",
"A: Makhana requires more space compared to grains, even for smaller quantities, and its price significantly jumps to 700 per kg or more in metropolitan markets, reflecting the increased demand and the importance of transportation in connecting supply with demand across regions.",
"Q: What are the health and nutritional benefits of makhana?",
"A: Makhana pop has enormous health benefits, including being low in fat but rich in protein, carbohydrates, and minerals. It is used in milk-based food preparations, snacks, and has various pharmacological activities such as anti-diabetic, anti-melanogenic, and anti-cytotoxicity action.",
"Q: How is makhana traditionally used in ayurvedic medicine?",
"A: The kernel powder of makhana is used in ayurvedic medicines to strengthen the spleen and kidneys, and it is considered a gluten-free food, rich in folate, beneficial for the development of a baby during the first trimester of pregnancy and effective for women at the post-natal stage.",
"Q: What is the calorific value of raw and puffed makhana seeds?",
"A: The calorific value of raw makhana seeds is 328 kcal/100g, and for puffed makhana seeds, it is 362 kcal/100g.",
"Q: What is the nutritional composition of makhana?",
"A: Edible portion of makhana seed contains 12.8% moisture, 9.7% protein, 0.1% fat, 76.9% carbohydrate, 0.5% mineral contents, and 1.45% iron, along with a good fraction of sugar, phenol, and ascorbic acid. Its amino acid index is higher than that of staple foods.",
"Q: How does makhana compare nutritionally to other dry fruits?",
"A: Makhana possesses a superior nutritional profile relative to other dry fruits such as walnut, almond, cashew nut, or coconut in terms of sugar, proteins, phenol, and ascorbic acid content.",
"Q: What makes the Kosi region of Bihar suitable for makhana cultivation?",
"A: The Kosi region of Bihar is naturally waterlogged, making it suitable for cultivation in field conditions, and to enhance its economic significance, standard agro-techniques such as improved varieties, climate, and cultivating system are employed.",
"Q: What are the benefits of using makhana in milk-based food preparations?",
"A: Makhana pop is used in milk-based food preparations like kheer, puddings, and pulses-based curry, contributing to a nutritious diet.",
"Q: How does makhana contribute to controlling health conditions like blood pressure and blood sugar?",
"A: Due to its dietary fiber content, makhana is good for controlling blood pressure, blood sugar, heart diseases, and anaemia.",
"Q: What are the pharmacological activities of Euryale ferox, a component of makhana?",
"A: Euryale ferox, a component of makhana, has been reported for various pharmacological activities including anti-diabetic, anti-melanogenic, anti-hyperlipidemic, hepatoprotective, immune-modulatory, and anti-cytotoxicity action."
}

  "Q1": "What is the recommended practice for land preparation for foxtail millet cultivation?",
  "A1": "Plough once with a mould board plough before the onset of monsoon, and harrow or plough twice with a local plough when the monsoon starts.",
  "Q2": "What is the time of sowing for foxtail millet in different regions of India?",
  "A2": "Kharif: July-August in Karnataka, July in Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh, 2–3rd week July in Maharashtra; Rabi: August-September in Tamil Nadu; Irrigated/Summer: February-March.",
  "Q3": "What is the recommended seed rate and optimum plant population for foxtail millet?",
  "A3": "Seed rate of 8 kg/ha, with spacing of 25–30 cm (row to row), 8–10 cm (plant to plant), and an optimum plant population of 4–4.5 lakh/ha.",
  "Q4": "What are the recommended seed treatments for foxtail millet?",
  "A4": "Fungicide: Ridomil MZ @2 g/kg, Carbendazim @2 g/kg; Bio-fertilizer: Azospirillum brasilense and Aspergillus awamouri @25 g/kg.",
  "Q5": "What are the recommended manures and fertilizers for rainfed foxtail millet crops?",
  "A5": "FYM: 5–7.5 t/ha, Urea: 52 kg/ha, DAP: 33 kg/ha.",
  "Q6": "What is the recommended practice for inter-cultivation and irrigation for foxtail millet?",
  "A6": "Use a tyne-harrow when the crop is 30 days old, and irrigate 2–5 times in summer depending on soil type and climatic conditions. Drain out excess rainwater to avoid waterlogging.",
  "Q7": "What are the recommended weed control and disease control practices for foxtail millet?",
  "A7": "Weed control: Isoproturon (0.5 kg ai/ha) (pre-emergent), 2,4-D (0.75 kg ai/ha) (post-emergent 15–20 DAS). Disease control: Rogue out downy mildew affected plants, and spray mancozeb @2 g/litre if diseases appear at early stages.",
  "Q8": "What are the recommended pest control practices for foxtail millet?",
  "A8": "1. Early sowing in May wherever possible, 2. Increase the seed rate one and a half times in late-sown crops, 3. Seed treatment with Chloropyriphos @2 ml/litre water for 1 kg seed or Imidachloprid @0.7 ml/litre water.",
  "Q9": "What are the recommended harvesting and threshing practices for foxtail millet?",
  "A9": "Harvest when the earheads are dry, either by cutting the whole plant with a sickle or the ears separately. Thresh after drying for a few days with a stone roller or by trampling under the feet of bullocks.",
  "Q10": "What are the recommended inter-cropping practices for foxtail millet?",
  "A10": "Foxtail millet can be intercropped with pigeon pea (5:1), groundnut (2:1), and cotton (5:1)."
}
